review.title: Social planning for social HRI
review.abstract: Making a computational agent 'social' has implications for how it perceives itself and the environment in which it is situated, including the ability to recognise the behaviours of others. We point to recent work on social planning, i.e. planning in settings where the social context is relevant in the assessment of the beliefs and capabilities of others, and in making appropriate choices of what to do next.

sections.heading: I. RESEARCH CONTEXT
sections.text: In fact, most people who are able to understand themselves and their environment have the ability to recognize other people's behavior at different levels - simple actions, goals, and intentions. Therefore, it is not enough to add just a few "social modules" to existing architectures, while most cognitive models need to be studied for a period of time, in terms of actions that have both practical and social implications.

sections.text: Although we focus on cognitive mechanisms as essential components of an integrated cognitive architecture for effective social robots and do some research on human communication patterns [39], we recognize that there are many issues that are important in such architectures that we do not attempt to address - spatial thinking [40], actions of dialogue [7], multimodal inputs [41], signaling of action [24], the link between perception and action [42], [43] and comparisons between logical thinking and other approaches such as game theory [44] and probabilistic thinking [45]... to name but a few!!
